animalOfTheDay.name: serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.

calendar.name: scorpion
facts: Scorpions glow under ultraviolet light due to fluorescent chemicals in their exoskeletons.
They can survive for months without food by slowing their metabolism.
Scorpions give birth to live young, which ride on their mother's back until their first molt.
Only about 25 of the 1,500+ scorpion species have venom deadly to humans.

calendar.name: sea cucumber
facts: Sea cucumbers can eject their internal organs as a defense mechanism and later regenerate them.
They play a crucial role in ocean ecosystems by recycling nutrients on the seafloor.
They breathe through their anus by pumping water in and out of their respiratory tree.
Some species can liquefy their bodies to squeeze through small spaces.

calendar.name: sea lion
facts: They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.

calendar.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.

calendar.name: sea turtle
facts: Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.

calendar.name: seahorse
facts: Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.
They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.
Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.
They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.

calendar.name: serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.

randomAnimals.name: goose
facts: Geese mate for life and can live over 25 years.
They fly in V-formation to conserve energy during long migrations.
They can fly at altitudes up to 29,000 feet.
Geese have excellent memories and can remember migration routes for life.

randomAnimals.name: mandrill
facts: Mandrills are the largest monkeys, with males weighing up to 80 pounds.
Their colorful faces and rumps become brighter when excited or dominant.
Mandrills live in large groups called hordes, sometimes with over 1,000 individuals.
They are omnivorous, eating fruits, insects, and small vertebrates.

randomAnimals.name: black mamba
facts: They're the fastest snake in the world, capable of moving at 12.5 mph.
Black mambas are actually brown or gray - their name comes from their black mouth.
Despite their reputation, they're actually quite shy and prefer to flee from humans.
Their venom can kill a human in as little as 20 minutes without treatment.
